chapter.htmlHeader: Omeprazole

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What dosage of omeprazole should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• CKS recommends the use of standard doses of omeprazole as used for other people with acid reflux disease, as there is an absence of evidence on dosage in pregnancy from controlled trials. For gastro-oesophageal reflux disease:
    • The recommended dose is 20 mg once daily, however, some people may have adequate relief of symptoms using 10 mg daily, so consider individual dose adjustment [ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2017]. In pregnancy, use the smallest effective dose [BNF 72, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What contraindications and cautions are associated with omeprazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe omeprazole if the person has a history of:
    • Hypersensitivity to the drug or its excipients.
    • Features suggesting malignancy — exclude malignancy before prescribing, as omeprazole can mask the symptoms of gastric cancer.
  • Prescribe omeprazole with caution for people:
    • With reduced body stores of vitamin B12 — omeprazole may reduce absorption of vitamin B12.
    • At risk of osteoporosis — proton pump inhibitors may increase the risk of hip, wrist, and spine fractures (especially at high doses or if the duration of treatment is long).

[BNF 72, 2016; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What adverse effects are associated with omeprazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Gastrointestinal adverse effects (such as nausea, vomiting, constipation, and diarrhoea) can occur with omeprazole. Because of their acid-suppressing effect, proton pump inhibitors may increase the risk of Clostridium difficile and other gastrointestinal infections.
  • Other less common adverse effects include:
    • Headache.
    • Dizziness.
    • Dry mouth, altered taste, stomatitis.
    • Increased risk of fractures (particularly in those taking omeprazole at high doses or for long periods of time).
    • Blood disorders (for example leucopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia).
    • Hepatitis, jaundice.
    • Depression, confusion, hallucinations.
    • Paraesthesia, myalgia, arthralgia.
    • Electrolyte disturbances such as hyponatremia and hypomagnesaemia.
    • Skin conditions, including:
      • Rash, pruritus, photosensitivity, Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
      • Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus — has been rarely reported in people taking proton pump inhibitors and can occur weeks, months, or years after exposure. Consider this as a diagnosis if the person develops lesions (particularly on sun-exposed areas of the skin) and arthralgia. It may be necessary to stop omeprazole treatment.

[BNF 72, 2016; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the drug interactions with omeprazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Drug interactions with omeprazole include:
    • Cilostazol — plasma concentration is increased with concurrent omeprazole use.
    • Clopidogrel — the antiplatelet effect of clopidogrel is reduced with omeprazole use.
    • Escitalopram (and probably citalopram) — levels are increased by 50% with omeprazole use. Monitor for SSRI adverse effects (for example nausea, diarrhoea, dry mouth).
    • Coumarin anticoagulants — the anticoagulant effect may be enhanced.
    • Phenytoin — metabolism is decreased, which may increase exposure to phenytoin. Monitor plasma phenytoin levels for the first two weeks after omeprazole is started and after any dose changes.
    • Rilpivirine — plasma concentration of rilpirivine is reduced by concurrent use with omeprazole.
    • Protease inhibitors, including:
      • Saquinavir — the plasma concentration of saquinavir is increased by concurrent use with omeprazole.
      • Tipranavir — the plasma concentration of omeprazole is reduced.
      • Atazanavir — proton pump inhibitors decrease plasma levels.
    • Itraconazole and ketoconazole — proton pump inhibitors decrease absorption of these drugs.
    • Methotrexate — excretion of methotrexate may be reduced with concurrent use of proton pump inhibitors, leading to increased levels and increased risk of toxicity.
    • Inducers of CYP2C19 and CYP3A4 (for example rifampicin and St John's wort) — omeprazole metabolism may be increased by these drugs, leading to lower serum levels.

[BNF 72, 2016; Preston, 2016; ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2017]
